full_text.full_text:
The Properties of Distances
▪ If d(x, y) is a distance, the following properties hold:
1. Positivity
– d(x, y) ≥ 0 for all x and y
– d(x, y) = 0 only if x = y 
2. Symmetry
– d(x, y) = d(y, x) for all x and y
3. Triangle inequality
– d(x, z) ≤ d(x, y) + d(y, z) for all x, y, and z
y
d(x, y) 
d(y, z) 
x
d(x, z) ≤ d(x, y) + d(y, z)
▪ These properties are useful because they express our intuition 
about a distance well
z

▪ If d(x, y) is a distance, the following properties hold:
1. Positivity

– d(x, y) ≥ 0 for all x and y
– d(x, y) = 0 only if x = y
– d(x, y) = d(y, x) for all x and y
– d(x, z) ≤ d(x, y) + d(y, z) for all x, y, and z
